I have to get ready for dinner. EDGAR’S MOTHER You’re abandoning me tonight?

And she slams the basement door shut, trapping her crazy husband downstairs. She seemed downright jolly about it.

(lights up) No... Do you like him, Helen?

liked it that way. The criminals ran free. But there was no law against keeping track of radicals. I compiled note cards on over 5000 names. And called the one Department that held a small piece of untested power.
The Department of Labor. The power to deport, sir.
But only to deport people who checked two boxes. They had to be foreign citizens. AND, they had to be working to harm the country.

Harvey’s Restaurant, sir?  58.

(we hear his nerves) No. To the White House. The car pulls out of the garage and into the atrium. Gian gates open letting them out onto Pennsylvania Ave. EXT. ROOSEVELT’S OFFICE - DAY Edgar sits outside Roosevelt’s office holding the file on lap, waiting patiently, watching the clock -- 5:30PM.

The President is ready for you, Mr. Hoover. And Edgar walks in, ready to fight for his job. INT. HARVEY’S RESTAURANT - THAT EVENING An old world, elegant restaurant. HARVEY’S RESTAURANT - LATER Edgar and Clyde have settled in to their booth.
It’s the same dance each time. They make me wait. They imagine I’m sweating, that they’re showing me who's boss. And I play along.
Did you play him the tape?
No. The transcript. But he didn’t want to read it. That was unique. He wanted me to tell him about it.
How you came across it?
No. I explained up front we had never expected to find Mrs. Roosevelt in the bedroom of a known communist agitator. Much less having what sounded like... an intimate moment. (MORE)
(anxious laugh) And that I needed his guidance in how to proceed. I wanted him to know he had an ally.
Before he had a chance to ask you to resign.
Exactly, but when I was done, he simply pushed the file aside. He seemed unconcerned with it... Clyde, The President of the United States is afraid.
Afraid of you?
Of a potential invasion from abroad. (to the passing Host) Sir, can we have a bottle of Dom?
Of course, Mr. Hoover. Clyde gives Edgar a look. This is unusual.
You're drinking now?
We're celebrating... I feel I can trust you with anything, Clyde--
I'd like to think so.
(a big secret) The President signed a secret order granting me increased power of surveillance. Secret surveillance of Communists and Radicals. Without warrant.
Is that legal?
Sometimes we have to break the rules if we are going to keep our country safe... (MORE)
(off Clyde’s concern) But to make sure I hadn’t heard wrong, I clarified it with Secretary of state Hull. He said, “Go ahead and investigate the cocksuckers.”
Vulgar.
Agreed. (searching Clyde’s eyes) I want to ask you something.
Feel free.
I need someone who understands what’s at stake, who I can trust. An Associate Director of the FBI... I know you’ve only been with us 12 months...
+--almost 18.
(strangely intimate) You're missing my point. Clyde, I want you to be my number two man.
I’m not one for the spotlight.
I need you, Clyde.
(considers, then) Under one condition. (Edgar smiles) Good day or bad, if we agree or disagree, we never miss a lunch or dinner together.
I’d have it no other way. The Host arrives with champagne, a reporter trailing him.  61.
Mr. Hoover, Mr. Walters from the Times is here to see you. The champagne pops. Edgar is as happy as he'll ever be.

Pull over.

HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - NIGHT Edgar is at his mother’s bedside. She lies motionless in sipping medicine / sherry. Edgar is devastated.

The body was blackened, the left leg missing from the knee down. A visible fracture on the skull. He’d suffered a violent blow to the head... I told them months ago, he must have fallen on the way down, with the baby in his arms. She turns her head, clearly in pain. Clearly quite ill.  62. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) We are the sinners, we tolerated lawlessness in the land until it grew to diabolical proportions... The baby’s blood is on all of our hands. On your hands, Edgar. A short time ago, I spoke with the President. He ordered me to employ the full force of the FBI in solving this case. The day of the criminal in America is over. There will be justice before the year is out. That is a promise from the FBI.
Mr. Hoover! -- Mr. Hoover! Edgar loves the new attention. Clyde focuses in on a sing reporter who seems less than impressed.

How many more pieces can I run on Lindbergh’s employees and relatives? I need something fresh.
And if the director gives you a piece of information, exclusively, how does the country benefit?
The country? (reading Clyde) A story on the FBI? (reading Edgar) On its young director?  63.
What angle?
(considers, then: ) With the inescapable demise of the American Outlaw, the new American hero is the FBI.
A story or a cover story?
I can’t promise a cover. But I have a pal in the radio business if you’re willing to share true life stories. Maybe even a comic book.

(tamps down his joy) I would only want the truth to be told. Nothing colorful. Just who we are. Who I am. What we do. Toulson smiles at the reporter. They all know what Edgar really wants -- fame -- for himself and his FBI. I began collecting the finest scientific minds in the country. INT. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE / A.G.’S LIBRARY - DAY The three pieces of the LINDBERGH LADDER are carefully brought into the temporary lab in the A.G.’s old library. He claims to be the world expert on wood analysis.
It’s easy to be the expert if you're the only one in the world with any interest.

Only as mad as you are... sir. The Attorney General storms across the hall toward Edgar.  65.
This was supposed to be a “temporary inconvenience”, Mr. Hoover. If you want your Sherlock Holmes playtime, I suggest--
Where do you suggest I go?
I suggest you take your case to congress and put my books back.
(turning red) Would you like me to tell the country we cannot solve the Lindbergh case because we can’t afford a proper labratory and the Attorney General won’t even let us use his library?
Fine. Now Get your science fair project out of here!
Edgar sits before a packed hearing. Clyde sits beside him

We must outsmart and outwit the foreign AND domestic criminal. THEY have chemists building bombs. We need chemists tracing their efforts. We must have the most advanced force in the world if we are to have the safest nation on earth.

That is true sir, but our car and bank robbery recoveries totaled 6.5 million last year, and our budget was only 2 million. Unlike other departments in Washington, we run a profit... And you cannot possibly quantify the value of our successes (MORE)
with Pretty Boy Floyd, Baby Face Nelson, Machine Gun Kelly. SENATOR MCKELLER takes the mic. He’s not half as friendly

But you take part, for instance, in the making of radio shows and comic books... I’ve seen several of these “G-men” programs, and your picture seems to be shown in conjunction with them quite frequently.

(very uncomfortable) We declined emphatically to lend any form of endorsement and had nothing to do with their production, furnished no advice, technical advice or other advice. Clyde leans back and tries not to look shocked -- this wa blatant lie. For the first time, Edgar starts to sweat.

The very advertisement said the broadcasts were, “True reflection, as contained in the OFFICIAL RECORDS... Based on actual cases from the files of Federal Bureau of Investigation, Saturday nights at 8 o'clock.” (Edgar is speechless) Mr. Hoover, what are your exact qualifications for your leadership position with this Bureau?
(his job now at risk) 19 years with the Department of Justice. 12 as Director.
And in that time, have you EVER Made an arrest, yourself?  67.
I have made investigations. I administer many cases at once, Sir.
That’s not what I asked. The comics show you with a machine gun, making arrests. Is that just fiction?
I am responsible for thousands of arrests, sir.
So you admit it’s PURE fiction. In fact it wasn’t you who hunted and captured John Dilinger at all. It was Agent Purvis, is that correct?
I have been in charge of all of these cases... but no sir, I have not personally made an arrest. Edgar’s blood is boiling, humiliated.
Edgar marches out, rambling at Clyde at a frantic pace.

We spend our lives working for justice, and the thanks we get is a political attack. Would they rather crimes go unsolved? Why is he fighting me? Start a file on Senator McKeller immediately. I want three agents on him at all times. Go through his trash. Photograph him at every dinner. Edgar arrives at his armored car and gets in. Clyde follo
Get out. You can walk back.
We have lunch. We don’t miss lunches. No matter what. Remember?
You pulled away from me in there.  68.
I’m sorry, Edgar, but it was a lie. An easily provable one. If he had pursued it, there’s no telling how much worse it could have been.
(a beat, then) Find out where Agent Purvis is. He is to be demoted immediately, or better yet, fired.
Firing the man who killed Dilinger would be a PR disaster.

Then he’1ll spend the rest of his career behind a desk. And tell him if he wants to keep that job, he’d best keep out of the papers. Edgar shuts the door leaving Clyde on the sidewalk. The c drives off. The “lunch promise” is already broken, but it not the punishment Clyde took it as -- Edgar is breaking down. He sets in on a panic attack. INT. I don’t know who to trust anymore, mother. Let me take you to a doctor. I can’t go on without you. Please, mother. We could go now. EDGAR’S MOTHER (barely a whisper) Faith, Edgar. Faith... Don’t wilt like a little flower. Be strong.
The hum of the engines in mid air, Edgar, Clyde, and 12 AGENTS have chartered a plane. Edgar is manic.
The arrest is mine to make, understood? You will strictly follow Agent Toulson’s orders. (kissing up) (MORE)

Agent Toulson is the finest agent in the Bureau today. His worth is second to none. In all of your careers, you can only dream of becoming half the agent he is now. Listen to his every word. The Agents nod out of duty. Toulson is uncomfortable.

What is it?
It’s from Lorena Hickock, the White House reporter with the bad breath... to Mrs. Roosevelt!
What are you going to do with it?

Nothing. I accused her of having an affair with a man, but Old Horse Face is having an affair with Bat Breath! A woman! I was wrong! Helen Gandy sticks her head in. Edgar clears the tears fr his eyes. He can’t stop laughing.  72.
Mr. Hoover, they’d like to see you in the labratory.
I’1ll be right there, Miss Gandy. (she goes) Clyde, the races begin in Del Mar next week. I was thinking of taking a quick vacation. I thought perhaps you’d like to join me.
(smiles, considers) I’ve never been to a horse race.
It’s wonderful. And between you and me, when I lose my bets, the track covers the losses.
And when you win?
They pay!
So where’s the thrill?
In the sun that comes down in the stands. The hotel rooms. The service. The dinners. The company. Come with me.
I would love to.
I’ll have Miss Gandy make all the arrangements. It will be perfect!
Edgar... I’m afraid I can’t now. But perhaps in a few months... if I start saving.
No. It’s covered. Completely.

You’ve done so much for me. For the Bureau. Consider it a thank you. (Clyde isn’t convinced) I’1l get a suite with adjoining rooms instead of separate rooms. That will be savings enough.
It’s a deal. (smiles warmly) You should go. They’re waiting for you in the crime lab... Mr. Hoover.

There are several kinds of wood here. Pine. Birch. Fir. And if you look closely, you will see that each has its own internal markings, rings and knots, and its own external markings, as in here, from the machinery that milled the raw timber. And these, that mark the tools used to build the ladder.

It was used for something else before the ladder was built.  74.
Yes. And it’s low grade sapwood with NO signs of weathering, so it was inside, not out. And the pine shows no signs of previous use. That tells us this ladder was built for THIS job. Nothing else.
How does this help us identify the kidnapper?
I need more money, sir.
For?

Postage. I need to write to every mill on the East coast to see if their blades match these marks. Edgar considers. Is this guy for real, or really nuts? He looks at the wood again, and ALL THE CONNECTIONS LIGHT UP

I want a report on each mill. And a map to track all leads. By the time I'm in New York, I want something to report, Mr. Koehler. INT. “G-MEN” MOVIE PREMIERE - NIGHT Up on the screen is the movie “G-Men.” Lighting quick Jam “Brick” Davis (JAMES CAGNEY) jumps through a window.

Those aren’t details I can share with a group of refined women. I couldn’t stand to make a single one of you shed a tear. But I assure you, we're on the case.

Only justice can bring reason back to their lives... but I might share one confidential clue with you. If you will swear secrecy. He holds out his pinky. They giggle, hold out theirs and a four way pinky pact. More laughter. Lela doesn’t let go his pinky. She’s falling for him. He gets quiet:

In the Bronx. On three occasions. And each of the shop owners who turned them in claim they received them from a man with a pointed chin... and a German accent. Anita gasps and cozies up to Edgar. Lela clocks it. She w him to herself. Clyde watches it all play out from afar.

Then no time like the present. This is my favorite song.  78.

(turning purple) Mr. Toulson, I think it’s t-t-time for us to go. We have a good deal of work t-t-tomorrow. I’m afraid I just don’t have t--t--time to dance. My sincere apology. N-- Now Mr. Toulson. This minute. And Edgar finally wiggles his way out of the table, clear running away from the women. Clyde follows. Lela and Ginger can’t contain their laughter. Edgar catch glimpse of it on his way out. He’s humiliated.
On his mother’s bed is a now giant album of Edgar’s press clippings with a new shot of Edgar from the premiere’s pr book. Edgar is crying and stuttering at her beside.

I--I--I d--d--d-don’t like to d-d-- d--d-dance, a-a-- EDGAR’S MOTHER Edgar, go look in the mirror and talk the way the doctor taught you to. Be my little Speedie. He stands up, looks in the mirror, straightens his postur and starts talking in his fast, “speedie” way, the way th world knows him -- it’s his stutter cure.

Yes, mother, I can spit my words out with precision, diction and clarity. I don’t like to dance. I don’t like to dance with anyone, but mostly I don’t like to dance with women, mother. It’s about time you knew. I find it humiliating and I refuse to be publicly humiliated. EDGAR’S MOTHER Edgar. Stop. (he does) Do you remember Barton Pincus?
(speedy in the mirror) His father was the watchmaker. He (MORE)

was 10 years younger than me, and you called him “Birdie” or “Daffy.” EDGAR’S MOTHER Do you remember what happened to “Daffy” after the school custodian discovered him in the hoop skirt and the flower bonnet?
He was made to stand outside our school wearing the skirt and bonnet as punishment. EDGAR’S MOTHER And did you ever wonder why we called him Daffy?
For his odd behavior. EDGAR’S MOTHER It was short for daffodil, Edgar. And do you remember what happened to little Daffodile Pincus?

Yes... He shot himself six weeks after he stood outside school in that skirt. EDGAR’S MOTHER That’s right. And I thank God every day that my own sons don’t suffer from his condition. Edgar. I'd rather have a dead son than a daffodil for a son. She closes Edgar’s album and wills herself out of bed. EDGAR’S MOTHER (CONT'D) Now I’1l to teach you how to dance.

Yes mother. Edgar cannot even face her. He can only look at her throu the mirror. It’s a heartbreaking moment. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Lights, cameras, Edgar is filming a new televised speech.  80.

It is imperative that we preserve and protect the morals of the American family. If the home is imperiled, if the home is destroyed, everything in our civilization crashes to its doom. Clyde watches from afar, surprised / concerned by Edgar's newfound passion for “traditional morality.”

AGENT SISK (CONT’D) His name is Richard Bruno Hauptmann.  84. EXT. I told you I’m not to be disturbed. INT. HELEN GANDY’S OFFICE - SAME TIME Old Helen can hear the sex recording through the phone.
Mr. Hoover. It’s urgent. I have Agent Shakin on from Dallas.-- INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER
My apologies Mr. Hoover, I told Miss Gandy to put me right through.
What is it, Agent, Shankin?
Sir, the President has been shot. (Edgar is stunned) He was just declared dead, sir.
Who knows about this?
No one, sir. I thought you should know before the press reports it.

Thank you, Agent Shankin. He hangs up. Even steely Hoover has to process the magnit of this moment. He walks into his outer office, consideri his next move. He focuses in on his NOW COMPLETED REPLICA ROBERT KENNEDY'S FIREPLACE. He picks up his phone and dia OLD HOOVER (CONT ’D) Get me Robert Kennedy... I don’t care where in McLean he is. Put me through immediately.
Robert Kennedy walks up to his phone, relaxed, unaware.
Mr. Hoover?  87.
Mr. Kennedy, The President has been shot. Hoover hangs up. He eyes the red buzzer on his desk. He unscrews the bulb and the light goes out.

The flags are all at half staff for Kennedy. Hoover doesn seem to notice. He’s got his eye on the 6th race of the d Toulson is by his side. Both are using binoculars, both s as the horses round the end headed toward the home stretc

The horses round the corner 30 years earlier in Del Mar. REVEAL: Edgar and Clyde, dressed to the nines, watching a similar race. They’ve clearly made it to their vacation. Their horse wins! It’s pure joy. These two are being trea like royalty, surrounded by DESI ARNAZ, BING CROSBY, JIMM DURANTE, LUCILLE BALL, and A FEW MOBSTER TYPES.

Clyde changes into a robe and checks his hair. It takes v little for him to be handsome. He’s far more interested i his race stubs, his treasures. He places them carefully i zippered pouch of his dop kit.

Edgar is in his own bathroom changing into a silk robe. H checks his hair, finds a grey and plucks it out. He slick the rest back. He brushes his teeth with precision and sp He walks out of his bathroom, through his bedroom, and in the central living room just as--
--Clyde enters from his own suite. Without words, Clyde p two cocktails. Edgar finds a radio station. Edgar turns and watches Clyde from behind, finishing thei drinks. It all feels very romantic.
Did you see his shoes?  88.
Desi Arnaz? The leather ones with the horrible buckles across the top? No didn’t notice them one bit.
You’d think with all of their money they’d have better fashion sense, or pay someone to have it for them.

And his fau-ginger wife, when she walked in, I was afraid a hunter might pull a rifle on that hat. Edgar imitates how it must have bounced each time she too step. Clyde is charmed. He sits. Edgar does the same. Cly puts his hand on Edgar’s. Edgar continues laughing for a - without taking his hand away. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) I care so very much for you, Clyde.
(gets up the nerve, then) I love you, Edgar. Edgar won’t look at Clyde -- who is looking right at him. YOUNG TOULSON (CONT’D) Are you okay?
Yes. Out of nerves or preparation, in the slightest of gesture Clyde wets his lip.
c-Can I ask you s-something?
Anything. Edgar removes his hand to reach for a drink he doesn’t ne
What do you think of Dorothy Lamour? The actress.
With Rudy Vallee at the Stork Club?  89.
That’s the one.
She’s a bit too camp for me.
Well, I’m thinking... of t-t-taking her up on a proposal.
For dinner?
No. We’ve already had dinners.
When?
On the weekends. When I’ve gone up to New York.
(that feels like cheating) I see.
What I’m asking is... I think it may be time for a Mrs. Hoover. (Clyde can’t even speak) You don’t like her?
Don’t make a fool of me.
I’m not.
(the big, scary question) Have you become... physical?
Yes. We have. (Toulson quietly fumes) You’d rather me be half a person, Clyde? Remain incomplete? Toulson throws his drink against a wall. Edgar shrieks.
Am I an incompletion?  90.
Pick that glass up.
No. I won’t. I have no reason to. Fire me. Now. Go on.

You are making a fool of yourself. And Clyde clears two more glasses on the bar onto the flo There is glass everywhere. Edgar is speechless. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) Clyde, and you have no shoes on. Stop this! Clyde gets up in Edgar’s face. It looks like he might fig him physically.

You will never tell me what to do again. You just lost that right. I see through you. You’re a scared, heartless, horrible, little man. Edgar throws a punch. It lands. Toulson throws one of his own. It’s a brutal fight. Years of pent up attraction. They crash to the floor. Clyde pins Edgar. He considers pounding his face in. Instead, he kisses Edgar full on th lips. They hold for a moment. Edgar hardly resists. Final Clyde pulls away.
(not meaning it) Don’t ever do that again.
I won't. Clyde checks himself for cuts and starts out of the room. He’s almost to his bedroom when Edgar stops him.
Don’t leave me, Clyde... Please. We have a second day of races. (hard words to form) I’m begging you.
(a long beat, then) If you ever mention a lady friend (MORE)

again, that will be the last day you share my company. Clyde goes. Edgar touches his lips, recalling Clyde’s aga his. A sensation he may never feel again. He calms his shaking, gets up, and starts collecting glass off the flo The sound of a GUNSHOT -- crosses the cut to:

Picking up where the race left off before the flashback - flags still at half staff: --as the horses round the corner to the finish, Old Touls feels a numbness in his right shoulder. He blinks his eye he’s seeing flashes. He shifts as if tripping, as if the ground just moved, and he sits. Hoover rushes to his side do others around them.
What is it, Clyde? (Clyde can’t answer) Get a doctor!
Flanked by TWO AGENTS and Miss Gandy, Hoover looks quite
He should be able to recover most of his function, but a stroke like this will limit the hours he can work. The information he can process. For a while at least... Are you okay, Mr. Hoover?
I played in the yard with my dog on Saturday. Perhaps it’s dehydration.
That could do it. But it may be wise to reduce your work hours as well. At your age it’s important to take leave.
Can I have some privacy please? The other Agents go. Hoover steams.  92. OLD HOOVER (CONT’D) If you ever denigrate me in front of my staff again, I will have you railroaded out of your profession.
(truly afraid) I apologize, sir.
What do you have for energy?
We have diet medications that tend to give a boost.
So I could lose a few pounds and have more energy?
You don’t need to worry about your weight sir, it’s solid weight. It’s ass kissing, but Hoover appreciates it.

We’ll schedule a daily visit. INT. HOOVER’S ADULTHOOD HOME / BREAKFAST TABLE - DAY Hoover and Toulson sit across from each other. Hoover tap hard boiled egg with a spoon and expertly peels it. Toulson struggles to grip his spoon. His entire right sid immobilized. His face droops. Hoover lets him struggle.
They’re giving him the Nobel Prize. (Toulson nods.) The degenerates and radicals are being lifted up internationally. It’s like 1920 all over again.
Don't...
When he finds out we have this tape, that we know the truth about his character, he will decline the award.  93.
Johnson... Wait. He ignores Toulson’s plea, focusing instead on Toulson’s struggle. He gets up, leans in close and peels it for him

I can’t understand you, Clyde. You have to work harder to enunciate. (Toulson looks concerned) We have no legal recourse. Law enforcement hasn’t kept pace with the improved tactics of today’s criminals.
What’s the... idea.
We have friends in the press. We plant stories with them to insure the activities of suspected radical leaders see the light of day.
They’1l trace it.

Only if they’re true. It’s Counter intelligence, Clyde. The more untrue the story, the more dramatic the impact. I’m going to deliver the hotel recording the day before the Nobel Prize with a personal letter. If he still accepts it. I’ll deliver the tape to the press.
The tape may... not be legal.
That’s why the letter won’t be from me. It will be a fictitious letter from one of his own.
There would be... no room for error. I’m not certain we could... insure that. Hoover doesn’t like the prudent advice or his “special friend’s” flagrant display of mortality.

I can’t understand you, Clyde. Hoover hits his own yolk. It’s hard. He tosses it down to dog who’s been waiting expectantly. OLD HOOVER (CONT’D) I need you back at the office tomorrow. It’s no time to relent.

I can’t. It’s not the answer Hoover wanted. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY The doctor fills a syringe with amphetamines, leans in to Hoover’s arm, and slides the needle gently in. CLOSE ON: Old Hoover’s eyes dilate. He’s juiced. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Edgar is sitting at the typewriter himself now. Writing. hear the words. It’s manic, emotional, a drug induced tir

Look into your heart. You know you are a complete fraud and a great liability to all of us Negroes. (This is a fraudulent letter) White people in this country have enough frauds of their own but I am sure they don’t have one at this time that is anywhere near your equal. I repeat... (return key, return key) I repeat... you are a colossal fraud and an evil, vicious one at that. You could not believe in God... Clearly you don’t believe in any personal moral principles. (is this all self-reflection?) You have turned out to be not a leader, but a dissolute, abnormal moral imbecile. (he reflects, then) There is only one thing left for you to do. You know what it is... There is but one way out for you. You better take it before your (MORE)

filthy, abnormal fraudulent self is bared to the nation. The letter is a bloody, inky tirade. He seals it in an envelope. It says as much about Hoover’s own state as it about the mysterious recipient. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Hoover is with a new writer, AGENT JONES. He almost looks black -- mixed race perhaps. Hoover is trying to process
Miss Gandy told me you stopped with Bruno Hauptman’s arrest. Should we start there?
Yes... Check for his address in earlier drafts...

Hauptmann is handcuffed, standing in the middle of the ro His wife walks in. Edgar’s focus shifts from a pricey STROMBERG-CARLSON RADIO to her expensive shoes. Officers her from embracing her husband. She starts to cry. Hauptm tries to comfort her -- in German:
Es ist nichts. Es ist Uber meine Gliicksspiel.
What did he say?
That this is about his gambling.
May I sit? He knows he’s been caught in a lie. He sits by the window
Where’s the rest of his money?
I don’t know what you mean. Or who HE is.
You don’t know who Charles Lindbergh is?  96.
Except maybe from the papers, no.
This isn’t the kind of money a carpenter makes, Mr. Hauptmann.

I made Wall Street investments. Agents in the adjoining room start ripping open Hauptman’ Mattress, but Hauptmann pays it no attention. He simply g out the window. Edgar takes note. He walks to the window, peers out, and sees the small, crude, garage fifty feet a INT. BRUNO HAUPTMAN’S GARAGE - LATER Agents tear up the floorboards in the garage. They find f dirt, grab a shovel, and dig into it and quickly find a j buried in a hole, but it is only filled with water.
Edgar stands in front of Hauptmann holding the empty jar.

Where is the ransom money, Bruno? Did you spend it all on your old lady’s shoe collection? His wife Anna’s shoes are in a pile in the middle of the floor. She’s having a nervous breakdown. Agents start carting out stacks of Hauptman’s papers, fil with his handwriting.
Where are you taking my things?
To the FBI, Mr. Hauptmann. Does that worry you?
You hunt the wrong man because I have accent, because you don’t trust immigrant. You are a bigot.
AGENTS cuff Hauptman to a chair. A NYPD OFFICER has a ham The lights go out. We hear punches, blows and screams.  97.
The mass of Hauptman’s papers and journals have arrived. Albert Osborne (the handwriting expert from earlier) is t to receive them.
Albert Osborne is isolated on a riser with 11x14 photosta blow ups of letters and words from Hauptman’s writings.

In both the ransom note and Mr. Hauptmann’s personal writings, he wrote, “haus” for house, “anyding” for anything,”gut” for good,” and “boad” for boat, And notice the inverted capital “N”s and “y”s that look like “j"s INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 With the mixed race agent.
But couldn’t those sorts of Germanic formations come from any number of immigrants? Aren’t those common translation mistakes?

You're right, Agent Jones. Alone it wouldn’t have been enough. So when my agents arrived to replace the local police, we searched again. INT. BRUNO HAUPTMAN’S GARAGE - DAY - 1934 FBI AGENTS are literally dismantling the garage. EDGAR IS STANDING WATCH. The NYC Police simply observe. Edgar is focused on a piece of wood he finds odd. It’s above the w bench -- a board nailed across two joists.
What purpose would a piece of wood like this serve? REVEAL: wood expert Koehler is now there too.

It doesn’t appear structural.  98. JUMP TO: AGENTS carefully pull the board off the joists, waiting to see if anything gives structurally. It doesn’t Behind it they finds TWO NEWSPAPER PACKETS. Edgar opens o carefully. Inside are ONE HUNDRED TEN-DOLLAR GOLD NOTES.

Remove all the joists. JUMP TO: ANOTHER AGENT finds a hidden shelf. In it is a O GALLON SHELLAC CAN. He pulls out the rags stuffed on top. Inside is $11,930 worth of ransom money. AT THE SAME TIME: Arthur Koehler finds Hauptman’s tool ch He opens it. It’s neat and organized. All of the tools ar place, except: the STANDARD 3/4 INCH CHISEL. He pulls Hauptman’s saw from the chest and examines it.
The same space the handwriting expert appeared in earlier now Arthur Koehler is explaining his own findings.

You see, no two saws make the same markings. This saw from Bruno Hauptmann’s tool chest makes markings identical to those found on the ladder used in the crime. I searched 1900-- (holds up a piece of wood) --factories across the country to see which blade made the other cuts on the ladder. I narrowed it down to one. Centralia lumber yard. Four blocks from Mr. Hauptman’s home. CLOSE ON: Edgar listens from a bench, seemingly alone, gi with this man’s scientific exactitude. INT. BRUNO HAUPTMAN’S ATTIC - NIGHT Edgar is with Agent Sisk and Arthur Koehler as they appro an attic corner and see -- an eight foot board is missing Koehler unwraps a long bag labeled -- “Rail 16.” It’s the original rail he pointed out to Edgar in the lab so long

Rail 16. It didn’t match the rest. And those extra holes. Why were they there?  99. He lays the wood next to the empty spot in the floor. It’ perfect match. The four extra holes match perfectly with nail holes in the floor joists.
Arthur is still in the white space.
The science is conclusive. Mr. Hauptmann built the ladder. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 The young, mixed race FBI Agent stops typing.
But did he do it alone?

(displeased with the question) He never confessed, but what sociopath ever does. The evidence was clear. He was indicted for murder in the first degree while perpetrating a burglary. In New Jersey, that is punishable by death.

January 2nd, 1935, a cold winter morning in Fleming New Jersey, and what has now undoubtedly been penned “The Trial of the Century” has begun. H.L. Mencken has called it, “the biggest story since the (MORE)
resurrection.” And from the looks of things, it may be bigger.

Your honor, I would like to call to the stand Mr. Charles Lindbergh. In a gray suit and shirt with a tie, Charles Lindbergh wa slowly and confidently up to the stand and takes the seat next to THE JUDGE. The room is hushed. Lindbergh looks through the crowd, to the defense stand, stopping on Anna Hauptmann. He remains calm, unreadable. WILENTZ (CONT’D) Picking up where you left off. You said you heard a voice, in the cemetary that night.
Yes. Very clearly. A voice coming from the cemetary, to the best of my belief, calling Dr. Condon. In a foreign accent, “Hey, Doctor.”
And since that time, have you heard the same voice?
Yes, I have.

And whose voice was it, Colonel, that you heard in the vicinity of St. Raymond’s Cemetery that night, saying, “Hey Doctor?” And for the first time, Lindbergh turns his gaze from Wil -- to Bruno Hauptmann. Emotionless, Strong:

Mr. Bruno Hauptmann, take the stand. We see A REPORTER who’s snuck a tiny film camera in under coat. He furtively aims it at the witness stand. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Agent Jones watches Hoover pulls the shades. The room goe dark. Hoover fires up a film projector... It’s B&W footag Hauptmann from the trial itself. You have had an opportunity in this court today to tell the whole truth. Have you told the truth?
I told the truth already.
And the statements you made to District Attorney Foley, did you tell him the whole truth?
To a certain extent
And to a certain extent you didn't tell him the truth, is that it? Silence from Hauptmann.
